chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Alright everybody, those are arbitrary arguments.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: When you invoke a function, you can pass in a varying amount of arguments.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Set up your parameter to be args for a varying amount of non-keyword arguments,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: or quarks for a varying amount of keyword arguments.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: You can set up both in your parameters, which we did for this exercise.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: And while everybody, those are arbitrary arguments in Python.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Hey everybody, so today I got to talk about iterables in Python.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: An iterable, it's a category.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Any object or collection that can return its elements one at a time is considered an iterable.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: If an object or a collection is considered an iterable, then it can be iterated over in a loop.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: For example, let's create a list of numbers.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Numbers equals a list.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I'll add the numbers one through five to keep it simple.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Lists are considered iterable.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We can use them within a for loop.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: In the context of a for loop, we're going to be given each element one at a time.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Each element that we're working with, we can give a temporary nickname.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's say number for every number in my iterable of numbers.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's just print each number.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: This will give us one through five.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: The name of the current element in our iterable should be descriptive of what we're iterating over.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: For example, I don't want to rename the current number that we're working with as something like blah, blah, blah.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: You know, this would work, but other people looking over your code might not understand what a blah, blah, blah is.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: And I don't blame them.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Each element that we're given from our iterable,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: the name should be descriptive of what we're given.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Or you might see item for every item in numbers, print each item.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: That's also a good choice.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Now you could even iterate backwards by enclosing our iterable within the reversed function.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: So take our iterable of numbers and reverse it.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Then we get the numbers five, four, three, two, one.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: If you would rather not print each element on a new line,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: we can replace the new line character at the end of print statements with something else.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Print is a function.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We can pass in a keyword argument of end.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Rather than end each line with a new line character, let's end with a space.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: This will space out each of the elements, or we could replace it with something else.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Or what about a dash?

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: After each element, append a dash character.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We could even add multiple characters such as a space, a dash, and a space if we so choose.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: It's up to you.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Touples are also iterable.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's convert our list to a tuple by enclosing our numbers within a set of parentheses.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: And I no longer want this reversed.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: For every number in my iterable of numbers, print each number.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Then again, we get the numbers one through five.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's cover sets.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I will create a set of fruit, which I will name fruits.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: For a set, enclose any values within a set of curly braces.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's add a string of apple, a string of orange, a string of banana, and a string of coconut.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: So with our for loop, let's say for every fruit in my iterable of fruits.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I will print each fruit.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: That would give me apple, banana, orange, coconut.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Now sets, they're actually not reversible.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I will attempt to enclose our iterable of fruits within the reversed function.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Here's what happens.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We have a type error.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Set object is not reversible.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Set you can't reverse.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's cover strings.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I will create a string of name.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Type in your full name.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I'll use my YouTube channel name.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: For every character in my iterable of name, I would like to print each character.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Maybe I would rather not have each character end with a new line.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I will set the keyword argument of end to be a space.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Last we have dictionaries, which are the most complicated.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's name this dictionary my dictionary.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Dictionaries you enclose with a set of curly braces, kind of like a set.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: But each element is a key value pair.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I will add a key of a with an associated value of 1.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: A key of b, which has a value of 2.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: A key of c, which has a value of 3.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: If you iterate over a dictionary, the dictionary is going to return all the keys, but not the values.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We'll test that.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: For every key in my iterable of my dictionary, let's print each key.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: This would give me the keys of a, b and c.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: But none of the values, 1, 2 or 3.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: If you need the values, we're going to follow this iterable of my dictionary, use the built-in values method.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: This will return all the values of your dictionary as an iterable.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: But let's rename a key as value, because now we're working with the values.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Then we're given all the values, 1, 2 and 3.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: If you need both the keys and the values, you're going to use the items method.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We'll be given both a key and a value.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Make sure that the value and the key are separated with a comma.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's print each key, followed by the value.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We get the key of a with its value of 1, b, 2, c, 3.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We can reformat the output however we want.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's use an F string.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I will add two placeholders.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's print each key equals then the value.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: A equals 1, b equals 2, c equals 3.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Okay, everybody.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: So those are iterables.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: An object or a collection that can return its elements one at a time is considered an iterable.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Meaning that object or collection can be iterated over using a loop.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: And while everybody, those are iterables in Python.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Hello again.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: So today I got to talk about membership operators in Python.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: They are the operators in and not in.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Their use to test whether a value or a variable is found within a sequence, which include,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: but are now limited to, strings, lists, tuples, sets or dictionaries.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Here's an example.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I'm going to create a word, a secret word.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's say Apple.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I'm going to turn this into a game.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I will have a user, guess a letter.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I will accept some user input.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Guess a letter in the secret word.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: What I would like to do is check to see if my letter is found in my word.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I can write the following statement.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: If our letter in our word, in is going to return a Boolean value of true if that letter is found or false if it's not.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: So if our letter is found, I'm going to print the following statement.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I'll use an F string.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: There is a add a placeholder.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Insert our letter.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Else, let's print.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I'll use an F string.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Our letter was not found.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's test this.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Guess a letter in the secret word.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I will guess a capital A.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: So all these letters are uppercase.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Do take note of that.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Is there an A?

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: There is an A.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's guess a letter that's not within this word.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Such as Z.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Z was not found.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: The in membership operator will test to see if a value or a variable is found within a sequence.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: If it is, it returns true.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: If not, it returns false.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Or for the inverse, you could say not in.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: If letter is not in word, we would have to flip these statements around.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: If this value or variable is not found in this sequence, it returns true.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Otherwise, false.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: So it does the opposite of N.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Guess a letter in the secret word.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Is there an E?

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: There is an E.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Is there a Q?

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Q was not found.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Depending on the statement you're trying to write, you can use either a value or a variable.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: If there is a value, you can use either a value or a variable.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Depending on the statement you're trying to write, you can use either in or not in.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Whichever makes more sense in that context.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's go over another example.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We were searching for a value or a variable found within a string.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's try a set.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: List, tuples and sets are going to behave similarly.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I will create a set of students.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: For a set, you need a set of curly braces.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's add a few student names.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Such as SpongeBob, PatchRake and Sandy.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I will have a user type in a student to search for.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We will accept some user input.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Enter the name of a student.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We're going to check if our student is in our sequence of students.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: If in returns true, let's print the following.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I'll use an F string.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Insert our student.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Is a student.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Else, we will print.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I'll use an F string.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Insert that student.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Was not found.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Enter the name of a student.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's search for SpongeBob.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: SpongeBob is a student.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Enter the name of a student.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's attempt Squidward.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Squidward was not found.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: And much like the first example, we can do the opposite.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: See if a value or a variable is not in a sequence.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We would have to switch these statements around.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Enter the name of a student.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Is Sandy a student.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Sandy is a student.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Enter the name of a student.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Is Larry a student.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Larry was not found.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Now we'll cover dictionaries.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I will create a dictionary of grades.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Student grades, like a grade book.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's say that the student of Sandy,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: she will be a key, has a value of A.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Squidward,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: the key of Squidward has a value of B.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: SpongeBob, he is also a key.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: SpongeBob has a grade of C.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Then Patrick.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Patrick has a grade of D.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Here is my dictionary of grades.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Then we'll search for a student.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Student equals input.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Enter the name of a student.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We'll check if, let me close this,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: if our student is found within grades,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: then I will print the following.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We're looking for keys.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Is there a matching key?

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: If we find that student, I'll make this an F string.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's display the associated value of that key.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Student.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Students.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Grade is, I'll add a placeholder.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Once we find a student, we have to get that value at the given key.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: To do that, we'll take our dictionary of grades at index of student.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: This will retrieve the value at a given key.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: If we don't find a student, we'll output the following.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Again, I'll use an F string.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Student was not found.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Now, if I search for a student, such as SpongeBob,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: we're given a grade.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We're given the value at that key that we're searching for.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's test Sandy.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Sandy's grade is A.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Squidward.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Squidward's grade is B.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: And Patrick.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Patrick's grade is D.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: But Larry is not a student.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: If I search for him, well, Larry was not found.

chunks.title: co

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We're going to create a variable of email.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: It's going to be a string.

chunks.title: co

chunks.title: co
